title: 107_s610
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Police Gun Buyback Assistance Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. Congress finds that decommissioned firearms sold by law enforcement agencies have been used in numerous crimes, including homicides and assaults. This includes instances like a white supremacist using a Glock pistol from Washington to shoot children at a Jewish community center and a postal worker. Additionally, stolen firearms from the Miami-Dade Police Department have been linked to crimes in Chicago, such as a shooting near a playground. The Act aims to reduce firearms on the streets by stopping law enforcement agencies from reselling decommissioned firearms, which have been used in crimes. Some departments destroy these firearms, while others still engage in reselling, including assault weapons. The Act aims to reduce firearms on the streets by stopping law enforcement agencies from reselling decommissioned firearms, including assault weapons. SEC. 3. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Attorney General may provide grants to States or local governments to purchase new firearms and destroy decommissioned firearms. To be eligible for a grant, a State or local government must have a policy that prohibits transferring decommissioned firearms to individuals and requires their destruction, with an exception for transfer to law enforcement agencies. The Act allows for the transfer of decommissioned firearms to law enforcement agencies. States or local governments receiving grants must use the funds to purchase new firearms. To apply for a grant under this Act, the chief executive of a State or unit of local government must submit an application to the Attorney General containing required information. Regulations for the grant application process are outlined in the Act. SEC. 5. REGULATIONS.

Within 90 days of the Act's enactment, the Attorney General must create regulations for grant applications, specifying required information and submission requirements for States and local governments.

SEC. 6. REPORTING.

States and local governments must report to the Attorney General within 2 years of receiving funds, ensuring future firearm purchases by law enforcement agencies can be made without transferring decommissioned firearms.

SEC. 7. DEFINITION. SEC. 7. DEFINITION.

Defines "decommissioned firearm" as a firearm no longer in use by law enforcement or needed for evidentiary purposes, "firearm" as defined in section 921(a)(3) of title 18, and "person" as defined in section 1 of title 1, United States Code.

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Authorizes $10,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005 to carry out the Act.
